@aiwalter , Here are my initial thoughts and understanding on this. 

I think your use of `initial_window` is more or less Ok (you may want to use 72 instead of 84 though because of the following) - 
* For each of the candidate parameters in the `param_grid`, the model is trained on the `initial_window` first. 
* Then the `window_length` of data is appended to the `initial_window` data (essentially expanding window, if you use `start_with_window`=`True`) and the prediction is made which is used for evaluation. So in your example, data will be expanded from 72 to 84 and then future prediction will be made beyond that and those will be used for evaluation. 
* This process is repeated until you reach the end of the data (keep appending window length of data and making prediction and evaluation.

There are a few caveats though based on my analysis. 

* I found that in some (maybe all?) cases, it is only doing 1 step ahead prediction in the expanding window phase. When I tried adding a forecast horizon of 12 points, it gave an error that this is not supported yet.
* When the window is expanded, in some cases (maybe all?), the model parameters are not refit. It retains the same model parameters that were learned in the `initial_window`. See discussion on this topic here (https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/621). I think for backtesting, you want to refit it at each expanding window.

@aiwalter, thanks for your suggestion - I think having robust functionality for quick evaluation and backtesting is a great idea.

However, in summary of my answer below:
* I do *not* think backtesting should be a class like `GridSearchCV`, butpart of  an "external" benchmarking module
* it would be great if you would like to contribute to building that!

So, why should backtesting not be a class like `GridSearchCV`?
Because backtesting, or more generally performance evaluation workflows, are not the same as tuning strategies.

A tuning strategy still is a forecaster/estimator, but a performance evaluation workflow isn't. A forecaster is subjected to a performance evaluation workflow. Both may use re-sampling (e.g., cross-validation or temporal re-sampling), but still they aren't the same kinds of formal objects.

For this same reason, `sklearn`'s `GridSearchCV` should not be used for benchmarking or performance evaluation, because instances of it are representations of estimators, not evaluation workflows.

Some more detail on this, in my opinion, crucial distinction between tuning and evaluation workflows can be found in Section 5.1 of this paper on AI toolbox software design: https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.04938 (compare: anti-pattern 4; we seem to have been pre-scient here :smiley: )

Somewhat confusingly, the same re-sampling technique can be used in a tuning workflow as well as in an evaluation workflow.
For example, cross-validation is used inside `GridSearchCV` - to obtain performance estimates which are then used in tuning - and in evaluation workflows - to obtain performance estimates.

In terms of software design, the former should be an estimator class (with a higher-order scitype), but hte latter shouldn't be, even if both use the same re-sampling technique.
Evaluation should be on the workflow layer, and calls subject to something like
`benchmark(estimator, Backtesting(config), metrics)`
or
`Benchmarking.run()` (after construction with config setting)

Does this distinction make sense?

Btw, @ViktorKaz has been working on the design of benchmarking workflows for a while.
The newest for `sktime` is in this extension proposal here: https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/pull/5
I would suggest you think of contributing and/or designing the evaluation workflow(s)?

There is an also earlier toolbox we've written for benchmarking of `sklearn` vanilla estimators, but it's still quite immature:
https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.03678
The idea was to re-design, and also introduce an abstract benchmarking interface for `sktime` at the same time.
